translated: Verses of the Elder Nuns .
The Group of Twenties
The Elder Sundarī’s Verses
“You used to eat your children,
your own little ones, in the past.
You were tormented day and night,

analyzed: atīva paritappasi  sā ajja sabbāni khāditvā
translated: so much so that you were on fire.🔽But today, O Brahmin woman,

analyzed: sata puttāni brāhmaṇī  vāseṭṭhi kena vaṇṇena
translated: having eaten all your hundred children,🔽why are you not tormented
by grief?”
“I have eaten many hundreds of children,

analyzed: ñāti saṅgha satāni ca  khāditāni atītase
translated: and many hundreds of relatives,
in the past, you and I, Brahmin.
But now, having understood the escape
from birth and death,
I do not grieve or weep,
nor am I tormented by grief.”
“This is truly amazing, Vāseṭṭhi,
that you speak such words.
Having understood whose teaching,
do you speak such words?”
“This Brahmin, the Buddha,
has come to the city of Mithilā.
For the sake of abandoning all suffering,

analyzed: dhammam desesi pāṇina  tassa brahme arahataḥ
translated: he teaches the Dhamma to living beings.🔽Having heard the Dhamma
of that Worthy One, free from attachment,
there I understood the true Dhamma
and dispelled the grief over my children.”
“I too will go,
to the city of Mithilā;
Perhaps that Fortunate One will be able to liberate me,
from all suffering”.
The brahmin saw the Buddha,
liberated, without attachment;

original: muni dukkhassa pāragū.🔽Dukkhaṁ dukkhasamuppādaṁ,🔽dukkhassa ca atikkamaṁ;
analyzed: muni dukkhassa pāragū  dukkham dukkha samuppāda  dukkhassa ca atikkama
translated: The Sage, who had gone beyond suffering, taught him the Dhamma.🔽(He taught him) suffering, the arising of suffering,
and the overcoming of suffering,🔽and the Noble Eightfold Path,
which leads to the end of suffering.
There, having understood the true Dhamma,
he asked for the Going-forth;
Sujāta, after three nights,
attained the Three knowledges.
“Come, charioteer, go,

analyzed: ratham niyyādayā ahima  ārogyam brāhmaṇim vajja
translated: and prepare the chariot,🔽and tell the brahmin lady,
‘The brahmin has gone forth,
Sujāta, after three nights,
attained the Three knowledges’.
” Then the charioteer, taking the chariot,
and the thousand (coins),🔽told the brahmin lady,
“The brahmin has gone forth,
Sujāta, after three nights,

analyzed: tissaḥ vijjāḥ aphassayi  etat ca aham
translated: attained the Three knowledges”.🔽“This chariot and the thousand (coins),
and the charioteer,
Having heard the one with the three knowledges,
I give you the full bowl.”
“The chariot is yours alone,
and a thousand, brahmin lady;
I too will go forth,
in the presence of the one with excellent wisdom.”
“Elephants, cattle, jewels, and earrings,
This delightful household wealth I abandon.
Your father has gone forth,
Enjoy the wealth, beautiful lady;
You are the heir in the family.”
“Elephants, cattle, jewels, and earrings,
This delightful household wealth I abandon.
My father has gone forth,
Afflicted by grief for his son;
I too will go forth,
Afflicted by grief for my brother.”
“May your intention be fulfilled,
what you wish for, beautiful lady;
Rise up, alms-food and gleanings,
rag-robes as your robe;
Overcoming these,
in the next world, without defilements.”
“Venerable lady, for me who am training,
the divine eye is purified;
I know my past lives,
where I lived in the past.
Through you, good lady,
The Elder Nun is beautiful to the Community;
The three knowledges have been attained,
The Buddha’s instruction has been done.
Please allow me, Noble Lady,
I wish to go to Sāvatthī;
I will roar out a lion’s roar
in the presence of the Buddha, the Best.”
“See, Sundarī, the Teacher,🔽golden-coloured, with a copper-coloured-skin,
The tamer of those hard to tame,
the Awakened One, fearless in every way.”

analyzed: passa sundarimāyanti  vippamuttam nirūpadhi  vīta rāgam
translated: “See, Sundarī is coming,🔽liberated, without attachment,🔽free from passion, detached,
one who has done what had to be done, without taints.
Having left Bārāṇasī,
she has come into your presence;
Your disciple, Great Hero,
Sundarī worships your feet.
You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
I am your daughter, Brahmin.
Born from the breast and mouth,
one who has done what had to be done, without taints.”
“Welcome to you, good lady,
it is not far for you to come;
For it is the tamed ones who come,
to worship the Teacher’s feet,
free from passion, detached,
one who has done what had to be done, without taints.”
… the Elder Nun Sundarī …
